elements.name: question1
elements.title: Are the jeans displayed and priced as a binding offer? Give reasons for your answer.
elements.correctAnswer: Yes, goods displayed in the shop window are considered a binding offer and must be sold at the advertised price.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Manuela actually wants to sell the jeans for CHF 150. However, she has mistakenly written CHF 140 on the display in the shop window. A customer now wants to buy a pair of jeans for CHF 140. Does Manuela have to sell the pants at the lower price? Explain the facts of the case.
elements.correctAnswer: Yes, this is an insignificant error that the customer was unable to detect. Manuela must therefore sell at least one pair of jeans for CHF 140.

elements.name: question15
elements.title: Would Manuela have to sell the pants if she had forgotten a zero in the letter and had only written CHF 15 instead of CHF 150? Give reasons for your answer.
elements.correctAnswer: In this case, Manuela would not have to return the trousers at the lower price, as this was a material error. The customer had to expect that this very low price could not be correct and that a mistake had been made in the letter.
